transcript.text: Bribery doesn’t always look like cash changing hands. Click on each reveal button to learn more.

instructionText.text: Click on each reveal button to learn more. You may need to scroll to read the full answer.
Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

popText.text: Bribery happens when someone is given anything of value in an attempt to improperly influence their decisions or actions.

flipCard.buttonImg: Person passing another a brown envelope

popText.text:
It can involve cash, but it can also include:
  • stock in a company
  • gifts or gratuities
  • excessive entertainment or hospitality
  • sightseeing or vacations, even when connected with a legitimate business trip
  • unwarranted rebates or excessive commissions
  • political or charitable contributions
  • jobs for customers, their family members or friends
  • unusual or disguised allowances and expenses
  • anything else of value to the recipient

flipCard.buttonImg: Person passing another a brown envelope

popText.text:
• Many countries around the world have enacted laws against bribery – even countries in which bribery was historically widespread.
  • Our policy prohibits bribery in any country where we do business; as a multinational corporation, our actions in one country can lead to enforcement in all other locations where we operate.
  • In many jurisdictions around the world, bribery is also a criminal offense and individuals can be charged, tried and sentenced for their involvement in a bribery scheme.

flipCard.buttonImg: Person passing another a brown envelope
flipCard.buttonText: Does it matter if you are giving or receiving a bribe?

popText.text: In almost all jurisdictions, it is just as unlawful to give a bribe, as it is to receive one. Johnson Controls policy prohibits both offering or receiving a bribe of any kind.
